{{NCAATeamFootballSeason |Year=2003 |Team=Kansas State Wildcats |Image= Kstate text logo.svg |ImageSize=200 |Conference=Big 12 Conference |Division=North |ShortConference=Big 12 |CoachRank= 13 |BCSRank= 10 |APRank= 14 |Record=11-4 |ConfRecord= 6-2 |HeadCoach=[[Bill Snyder]] |OffCoach= Del Miller / Greg Peterson |DefCoach=[[Bret Bielema]] |StadiumArena=[[Bill Snyder Family Stadium|KSU Stadium]] |Champion= Big 12 Champions
Big 12 North Champions |BowlTourney= [[2004 Fiesta Bowl|Fiesta Bowl]] vs. [[2003 Ohio State Buckeyes football team|Ohio State]] |BowlTourneyResult= Lost 35-28 }} {{2003 Big 12 football standings}} The '''2003 Kansas State Wildcats football team''' represented [[Kansas State University]] in the [[college football]] [[2003 NCAA Division I-A football season|season of 2003-2004.]] The [[Kansas State Wildcats football|team's]] head football coach was [[Bill Snyder]]. The Wildcats played their home games in [[Bill Snyder Family Stadium|KSU Stadium]]. The team finished the season with a win-loss record of 11 and 4, and a [[Big 12 Conference]] record of 6 and 2. They shocked the College Football world with a stunning 35-7 victory over the #1 ranked [[2003 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma Sooners]] in the [[2003 Big 12 Championship Game|Big 12 Championship Game]]. With their first conference Championship since 1934, they earned the right to play in one of the premiere [[Bowl Championship Series]] bowl games, the [[2004 Fiesta Bowl]] where they were defeated by the [[2003 Ohio State Buckeyes football team|Ohio State Buckeyes]], 35-28. The Wildcats played 15 games, most in school history. The Wildcats scored 549 points, good for third all-time at Kansas State.[http://www.cfbdatawarehouse.com/data/div_ia/big12/kansas_state/most_points_season.php Points scored fact] ==Schedule== {{CFB
